sn2.25:1.2: On one occasion a number of bhikkhus were dwelling among the Kosalans in a little forest hut on a slope of the Himalayas—restless, puffed up, personally vain, rough-tongued, rambling in their talk, muddle-minded, without clear comprehension, unconcentrated, scatter-brained, loose in their sense faculties.
sn2.25:2.1: Then, on the Uposatha day of the fifteenth, the young deva Jantu approached those bhikkhus and addressed them in verses:
sn2.25:3.1: “In the past the bhikkhus lived happily,
sn2.25:3.3: Without wishes they sought their alms,
sn2.25:3.4: Without wishes they used their lodgings.
sn2.25:3.6: They made an end to suffering.
sn2.25:4.1: “But now like headmen in a village
sn2.25:4.2: They make themselves hard to maintain.
sn2.25:4.3: They eat and eat and then lie down,
sn2.25:5.2: I here speak only about some:
sn2.25:6.1: To those who dwell in negligence.
sn2.25:6.3: As for those who dwell in diligence,
sn2.25:6.4: To them I humbly pay homage. ”
